Doctor: WELCOME
Patient:
DESCRIPTION
Your patient, Amani Roberts, has been referred to you by her oncologist with her swallowing problems. She is 38 years old. She was recently treated for stage 2 hypopharyngeal cancer. Assess her condition and make a plan for appropriate follow-up action.

Click here to interact with the patient

Doctor: Kia ora, good morning Amani
Patient: Hi!

Doctor: My name is xxx. I'm a  speech language therapist
Patient: Hi!

Doctor: Your oncologist has referred you to me. Can you tell me a bit about what's been going on?
Patient: I've been having trouble swallowing. When I eat it feels like the food is sticking in the back of my throat. I have to swallow a lot to get it down and sometimes I think I'm choking. I have to drink a lot of water as well.

Doctor: That must be a bit scary.
Patient: Yes

Doctor: Do you have trouble drinking?
Patient: Drinking isn't really an issue. Sometimes I choke a little but nothing major. I've been drinking a lot of water because my mouth is so dry all the time.

Doctor: Do you have trouble with your saliva in your mouth?
Patient: I’ve started carrying a water bottle around with me everywhere I go since radiation, because my mouth is so dry and sticky. It’s such an uncomfortable feeling having a super dry mouth. The water helps a bit.

Doctor: That's a good strategy
Patient: Yes

Doctor: Have you seen a speech language therapist before?
Patient: I haven't seen anyone for my swallow. My oncologist asked me to see you about it.

Doctor: OK. Great.
Patient: Yes

Doctor: So what food feels like it's sticking in your throat?
Patient: If I take a bigger bite than normal or eat something tough, it feels like food gets stuck in the back of my throat. I have to swallow multiple times and drink water to get it down.

Doctor: Are you on a special diet?
Patient: I have to eat a lot of soft foods that are easier to swallow like soup or rice, or cooked vegetables. I can't eat red meat anymore or salad.

Doctor: Does this swallowing issue take away your enjoyment of feed?
Patient: No one else has had problems with swallowing.

Doctor: So who do you live with?
Patient: My husband and I have two children. A boy who's 8 and a girl who's 5.

Doctor: Do you feel well supported at home?
Patient: It's been stressful going through cancer treatment. My husband has been very supportive. We try to not burden our kids with this and keep their routines as normal as possible.

Doctor: That sounds hard.
Patient: Yes

Doctor: Do you smoke cigarettes?
Patient: I've never smoked in my life!

Doctor: And how about alcohol>
Patient: I like to drink white wine sometimes at night to relax.

Doctor: Have you been in hospital recently?
Patient: I was hospitalised during surgery for cancer.

Doctor: Do you have any other conditions?
Patient: Other than cancer, I have high blood pressure. The cancer is in remission now. Before the diagnosis I was relatively healthy. I had my adenoids removed when I was a kid but otherwise everything was fine.

Doctor: OK great. Have you had pneumonia before?
Patient: I haven't had any infections recently.

Doctor: When was your cancer diagnosed?
Patient: I was diagnosed with stage 2 hypopharyngeal cancer 6 months ago. I had surgery and radiation and now the cancer is in remission.

Doctor: Congratulation!
Patient: Hi!

Doctor: How are you feeling about your swallowing?
Patient: I've been feeling pretty low. It's been so hard to swallow the last few months and I'm worried it won't get better plus I am in pain all the time.

Doctor: I'm sorry to heat that. That must be hard, especially with children at home.
Patient: My husband and I have two children. A boy who's 8 and a girl who's 5.

Doctor: Is it hard to swallow pills?
Patient: I can swallow my pills with some extra water.

Doctor: Is there a time of day that swallowing is easier?
Patient: I have problems with my swallowing throughout the day.

Doctor: How do you eat meals at home?
Patient: I eat dinner with my husband and kids and lunch by myself. Usually something easy to eat so I don't choke when I'm alone.

Doctor: DO you go out to eat at all?
Patient: We just eat at home since the cancer. I've been avoiding going out to eat with friends. There is so much food I can't eat. I don't want people to see me in pain while I'm eating or to try to cheer me up. It's hard to feel optimistic when I can hardly eat.

Doctor: How does your husband manage all this?
Patient: It's been stressful going through cancer treatment. My husband has been very supportive. We try to not burden our kids with this and keep their routines as normal as possible.

Doctor: Are you worried about the choking?
Patient: I’m very anxious I might choke. My mouth is so dry that food gets stuck in my mouth. Some days just the thought of eating gives me anxiety.

Doctor: That's hard - I'm sorry to hear it.
Patient: Thank you.

Doctor: Does medication help?
Patient: Ibuprofen can help with the pain at least a little bit. Sertraline is helping with the stress. I also see a therapist. Megace seems to be working because I've gained some weight in the last two months. My blood pressure is fine on Diurin.

Doctor: That's a lot of medication
Patient: Ibuprofen can help with the pain at least a little bit. Sertraline is helping with the stress. I also see a therapist. Megace seems to be working because I've gained some weight in the last two months. My blood pressure is fine on Diurin.

Doctor: Did you lose some weight?
Patient: Last I checked I weighed 52 kilos. I lost a lot of weight during treatment. I wasn't able to eat much at all. I'm on an appetite stimulant and it seems to be working. I've put on some weight. But I'm still not eating as much as I used to. To be honest, food doesn't taste the same to me now.

Doctor: Have you lost your pleasure in food?
Patient: Food tastes different since the radiation therapy so I haven't been that into eating recently. I used to get really excited when my husband was going to cook dinner. He's a fantastic cook but now I have to force myself to eat whatever he makes.

Doctor: DOes he do most of the cooking at the moment?
Patient: My husband cooks our dinners most of the time. He's taken over from me since the cancer treatment. I get the kids' lunchboxes ready and make lunch for myself during the day.

Doctor: Well done. Sounds like you are boht doing really well.
Patient: Okay

Doctor: What do you want to achieve with me?
Patient: I would like to be able to swallow without pain and choking. It would be amazing if food tasted like it used to.

Doctor: Great - okay.
Patient: Yes

Doctor: Have you had any assessment or examination of your swallow before?
Patient: I haven't had my swallowing tested.

Doctor: I would like you have have an examination using a machine to see what is happening
Patient: I'm not sure what that means exactly. Can you explain, please?

Doctor: We can look at your swallowing and see where the difficulty for your swallow is. Would you be willing to have this assessment done?
Patient: Okay. What will this involve?

Doctor: You will be awake and swallowing some food and liquid.
Patient: Drinking isn't really an issue. Sometimes I choke a little but nothing major. I've been drinking a lot of water because my mouth is so dry all the time.

Doctor: Are you better at different times of the day?
Patient: I have problems with my swallowing throughout the day.

Doctor: What are your main concerns?
Patient: My swallowing keeps getting worse and I am worried it will not get better.

Doctor: Do you not see improvement at the moment?
Patient: Okay. Thank you.

Doctor: How is your voice quality?
Patient: My voice sounds pretty much the same as before the treatment. Maybe a little hoarse. I don't have any problems with my speech.

Doctor: Are you managing financially?
Patient: Food definitely tastes different since the radiation therapy. It's so disappointing when I eat my favourite foods and they taste wrong. And the pain when I swallow makes me want to skip meals altogether.

Doctor: Do you skip many meals?
Patient: I've been eating less because food tastes strange to me now. I have breakfast, lunch and dinner but my portions are much smaller than I used to eat. I can't eat much in one go because it's really painful.

Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that.
Patient: Thank you.

Doctor: Do you see friends often?
Patient: I’ve been feeling pretty low, so I’ve been avoiding meeting friends. I often feel like I'm not going to be good company. My therapist suggested I try and make an effort to socialise more.

Doctor: That is a good idea
Patient: Yes

Doctor: What are you seeing your therapist for?
Patient: Seeing the therapist has helped me manage my stress. Sertraline helps too. Sometimes it's hard with the cancer and family stuff.

Doctor: That's good that it helps
Patient: If food gets stuck I have to drink a lot of water and swallow a lot to get it down. I cough sometimes too when I swallow. It can help if I cut my food into small bites and avoid tougher foods.

Doctor: Ok, so what size bites do you need to cut them into?
Patient: If food gets stuck I have to drink a lot of water and swallow a lot to get it down. I cough sometimes too when I swallow. It can help if I cut my food into small bites and avoid tougher foods.

Doctor: Does mealtime take longer?
Patient: It takes me much longer to eat food I have to chew even if I take small bites. Especially since I get so worried about having a choking fit and I end up eating way more slowly than I probably have to. If I eat something like soup I can eat pretty normally. My meals can take 30 to 40 minutes.

Doctor: That sounds like a long time.
Patient: Yes

Doctor: Do you get tired?
Patient: I feel tired and weak when I haven't been able to eat for a while.

Doctor: So you feel tired and weak from not eating, but eating also makes you tired
Patient: I feel tired and weak when I haven't been able to eat for a while.

Doctor: Do you often not eat?
Patient: I eat dinner with my husband and kids and lunch by myself. Usually something easy to eat so I don't choke when I'm alone.

Doctor: Do you get exhausted from eating?
Patient: I feel tired and weak when I haven't been able to eat for a while.

Doctor: Do you see people in the community?
Patient: I have regular oncology appointments and I see a psychologist.

Doctor: What about visiting your children's school?
Patient: My husband and I have two children. A boy who's 8 and a girl who's 5.

Doctor: Do you feel like you can socialise at the moment?
Patient: I’ve been feeling pretty low, so I’ve been avoiding meeting friends. I often feel like I'm not going to be good company. My therapist suggested I try and make an effort to socialise more.

Doctor: Goodbye
Patient: Goodbye
